Among feminist booksellers, there was a sense of fewer
feminist books being published by mainstream publishers,
and more books being published by university presses. And
a solidly increasing list of books from the small, but not
primarily feminist, press. Feminist publishers, of course
are publishing more books than ever. While there was
concern about the apparent decrease in the number of
feminist books being published by mainstream publishers,
steadily rising sales figures in all the stores present
indicated that this is a perceptual problem on the part of
main-stream publishers rather than a reduction of interest
in feminist books in the marketplace or a lack good books
available to be published. It seems to be that every few
years a rumor circulates like a patriarchal flu on
publisher's row indicating that the market for feminist
books is passe. Usually it slows things down for a season
or two, and then evidence to the contrary moves in, and
they recover their good sense and go back to more typical
publishing patterns. Hopefully the current situation is
temporary and recovery will set in soon.
For FBN, it was a convention of distributing
advertising rate cards, advertising packets, selling
mailing lists to publishers and making advertising
contacts. Not to mention getting FBN into the hands of
booksellers who need it.
